arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The collection is organized into eleven series: Ted Macdonald Cultural Survival records; Ted Macdonald PONSACS records; Administrative and financial records; Office files; Bazaar and publicity records; Millennium records; Cultural Survival Quarterly records; Cultural Survival Quarterly; Cultural Survival reports and publications; Indigenous and indigenous issues video library; and Indigenous and indigenous issues reference library.

custodhist.head: Custodial History
custodhist.p: Digital Collections & Archives staff solicited this collection in part because DCA already held the papers of Ellen Lutz, former Fletcher School faculty member and Executive Director of Cultural Survival from 2004-2010. Following the acquisition and processing of the Ellen L. Lutz papers, which include a series of Cultural Survival files, Digital Collections & Archives staff reached out to Cultural Survival and agreed to preserve the latter's historically significant organizational records. Susanne Belovari, Archivist for Reference and Collections, appraised material at Cultural Survival's office in Cambridge, MA. The bulk of the material in this collection was then sent from Cultural Survival in an accession of 113 boxes on September 7, 2012. During delivery, one box tipped off a pallet and landed on a cup of iced coffee. Veronica Martzahl, Records Archivist, and Susanne Belovari worked to clean and dry the affected papers. Only minimal staining occurred on a portion of the materials in this box, although original order was lost.

Materials from series 1 and 2 were donated by Ted Macdonald under a separate donor agreement. Macdonald had stored these records in his house since 1995. This material arrived as an accession of 25 boxes on September 13, 2012.

This collection is a limited subset of the records that were generated by Cultural Survival in their daily activities. Other records may be missing due to Cultural Survival office moves, organizational reliance on interns, and staff members taking records home. Some early Cultural Survival records may also be in the David Maybury-Lewis papers at Harvard, which have not yet been processed as of May 2014. Records of some projects in particular, especially Cultural Survival Enterprises, do not appear to be present in large numbers.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: This collection was processed between November 2012 and April 2014 by Tim Walsh, Morgan VanClief, and Elizabeth McGorty, graduate Archives Assistants, under the supervision of Susanne Belovari, Archivist for Reference and Collections.

Material in the first two series, which consist of Ted Macdonald's files, was accessioned separately from the rest of this collection and has a separate donor agreement. Effort was made to keep the original arrangement system used by Macdonald and his staff, which organized files by countries and continents, as indicated by fragments of country indices found in the collection. A few files consisting of Macdonald's personal and class notes were removed from the collection and returned to the donor.

Material accessioned from Cultural Survival's offices had little discernible original order upon arrival at DCA. Some personal material, including popular culture magazines, was mixed in with Cultural Survival records. These were weeded and either returned to Cultural Survival or destroyed upon approval. Additionally, the accession included some material that had not been appraised by DCA staff, including slides of photographs used in Cultural Survival Quarterly that have significant copyright issues. These were returned to Cultural Survival, along with unneeded duplicates of Cultural Survival reports and promotional materials.

Overall, the material was in good condition and required minimal preservation work. Original labels were stapled onto folders to ensure that they do not fall off. Rusty staples and clips were removed; fasteners not causing evident damage were left as is. Material on faded thermal paper and carbon copy paper was copied, and both originals and copies were kept except in those cases where the originals were causing damage to surrounding records. Slides were largely left in their original sleeves, except in those cases where the sleeves exhibited obvious dirt or damage. Some large, fragile maps have been unfolded and stored in DCA map cases. Audio and video tapes were rewound and checked to ensure that write-protection tabs were broken off. Tapes in sturdy plastic cases without obvious signs of damage were kept in their original cases. Tapes in paper sleeves and loose tapes were rehoused in archival-quality cases.

A number of born-digital records on aging physical media were included in the accession from Cultural Survival. As of May 1, 2014, files from 155 3.5" floppy disks, 15 zip disks, 19 CDs, and 15 DVDs have been copied from their original media, bagged, and stored on backed up network drives. These files await further processing. One box of unstabilized media remains, including a few virus-infected floppy and zip disks and a number of 3.5" Mac-formatted double density floppy disks that will require specific hardware to read.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection contains project files, correspondence, administrative and financial records, publications, audio tapes, video tapes, curricula, photographs, slides, and promotional materials created by Cultural Survival. Also included in the collection are a number of publications and audiovisual materials created by indigenous peoples and sympathetic non-profit organizations and subsequently collected by Cultural Survival staff. The bulk of the material dates from 1979 to 2005. Many of the records document Cultural Survival Projects and Special Projects in Central and South America, Africa, Asia, Australia, and North America, as well as Cultural Survival's research and educational projects. Many of these project and research files were kept by Ted Macdonald, Cultural Survival's first staff member, who preserved the most complete collection of early project files. This collection also contains records relating to Cultural Survival Bazaar trade festivals; the 1992 British and US public television video series Millennium: Tribal Wisdom and the Modern World, hosted by and focused on the work of Cultural Survival founder David Maybury-Lewis; and a nearly full run of Cultural Survival Quarterly, Cultural Survival's flagship publication.

Some materials may be restricted due to legal or privacy concerns. In addition, rights issue to the images may be complicated in an attempt to maintain cultural sensitivity. Mark Camp, Deputy Executive Director of Cultural Survival, notes: "As an Indigenous rights issue, Cultural Survival now, in most cases, considers it a best practice to obtain permission from the subject of the photo in addition to that of the photographer. Also, some cultures have strong taboos and prohibitions against reproducing images of deceased persons. In some cases, recent international agreements govern the use of such images."

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Cultural Survival was founded in 1972 by David and Pia Maybury-Lewis, Evon Zartman Vogt, and Orlando Patterson as a tax-exempt nongovernmental organization based in Cambridge, MA seeking to promote the human and political rights of the world's indigenous peoples and ethnic minorities. Since its first years, interns have played a significant role in the day-to-day operations of Cultural Survival. In 1979, the organization hired its first full-time staff member, Theodore (Ted) Macdonald, and soon afterward also added Jason Clay to its payroll. Together with a global personal network of anthropologists and ethnologists, Cultural Survival developed projects, a research program, and a series of publications, and worked to secure funding for programs supporting indigenous peoples and causes in the field. From its early years, Cultural Survival has also put on the Cultural Survival Bazaar, an annual or semi-annual festival designed to make indigenous art visible and give indigenous artisans a market for their work, for many years organized by Pia Maybury-Lewis. In more recent years, Bazaars have also served as a way for Cultural Survival to raise funds and increase awareness of its programs supporting indigenous issues.

Beginning in the 1980s, Cultural Survival received substantial funding from the Ford Foundation, the World Bank, and the US Agency for International Development to carry out Cultural Survival Projects. The original focus of these projects was largely political organizing and resource management in Central and South America, reflecting the personal contacts of Cultural Survival staff. With the additions of Dominique (Nickie) Irvine and Mac Chapin to its staff, Cultural Survival added de facto offices in California and the D.C. area, and continued to expand the number and geographic diversity of the projects it supported. By 1986, Cultural Survival was supporting projects in, among other locations, Brazil, Bolivia, Chile, Colombia, Costa Rica, Ecuador, Mexico, the Middle East, Namibia, Nepal, Paraguay, Peru, and Venezuela.

Starting in 1983, Cultural Survival also supported what they called Special Projects – "projects designed, managed, and funded by anthropologists, development specialists, and indigenous peoples with very close ties to Cultural Survival who use[d] the organization's 501(c)(3) status and, in some cases its accounting services, to carry out their work." Special Projects had to be approved and reviewed by Cultural Survival's Board of Directors but, unlike Projects, maintained a high level of autonomy in their day-to-day operations and were generally not funded by Cultural Survival. Special Projects have been supported in Central, South, and North America; Africa; Asia; and Europe.

In 1989, Cultural Survival established Cultural Survival Enterprises (CSE), a "non-profit trading division that developed and marketed products" with the intention of "generating income for Indigenous people who were struggling to protect their lands and traditions within rainforest regions." The most commercially successful and widely known of CSE's products was Rainforest Crunch, a Ben & Jerry's ice cream flavor containing nuts harvested from the Amazon rainforest. During this time, Cultural Survival's staff size and costs increased significantly.

In order to manage the increasingly complex organization and to meet the requirements of funding agencies, Cultural Survival hired Pam Solo, a MacArthur fellow perhaps best known for her peace work related to nuclear arms, as its first Executive Director in 1990. By late 1991, Cultural Survival had 31 employees and a number of interns. A breakdown of previously profitable partnerships with The Body Shop and others, significant loan debt, and increased operation costs eventually led to financial trouble and external criticism. Cultural Survival responded by phasing out the CSE program and reducing staff to minimal levels. By 1996, Cultural Survival had 6 staff members on its payroll.

Throughout the 1990s, Cultural Survival decreased its financial support of Projects and Special Projects but continued to sponsor and publish research on issues relevant to indigenous people. This occurred largely in collaboration with the Program on Non-Violent Sanctions and Cultural Survival (PONSACS) at Harvard University's Weatherhead Center for International Affairs, which was formed in January 1995 as a formal merger of Cultural Survival Center, the research wing of Cultural Survival established in 1991, and the former Program on Nonviolent Sanctions at Harvard specializing in nonviolent alternatives to conflicts in order to preserve cultures and peoples. PONSACS was directed by David Maybury-Lewis from 1995-2005, and hired Ted Macdonald as Assistant Director following the latter's departure from Cultural Survival. Given the close ties between the two organizations, PONSACS lent support to Cultural Survival and its programs.

During this time Cultural Survival research continued also through its Scholars and Specialists Network, established in 1991. The Network originally consisted of some 150 anthropologists, ethnologists, and other scholars who "contributed timely and reliable data for the 1993 Cultural Survival Publication, the State of the Peoples: A Global Human Rights Report on Societies in Danger." Before being abandoned, the Network database contained the names and contact information of over 1,000 scholars, and was used to circulate research, news received by indigenous groups, and position papers.

Cultural Survival also played a limited role in the 1992 British and US public television video series Millennium: Tribal Wisdom and the Modern World hosted by and focusing on the work of David Maybury-Lewis. Although some Cultural Survival staff hoped to see the organization play a larger role in the series, ultimately Cultural Survival's contribution was limited to promoting the series to its networks of members and at several publicity events across the nation.

During the 1990s, Cultural Survival increasingly devoted time and attention to its educational programs. The Curriculum Resource Program developed curricula about ethnic diversity and indigenous peoples in the US and around the globe intended for use by middle and high school students. Curricula were tested with students from New England high schools and used to organize student conferences. At these Cultural Survival-run conferences, students were able to meet indigenous people and activists, and discuss issues affecting indigenous peoples outside of the classroom.

In addition, Cultural Survival has been widely known for its publications. Cultural Survival Quarterly, which started as Cultural Survival Newsletter from 1976-1981 and has existed in its current form since 1982, has an international readership and has been widely circulated in schools and universities. In addition to Cultural Survival Quarterly, Cultural Survival has had several series of publications, including Reports, Special Reports, and Occasional Papers, as well as online outlets such as Active Voices and the Ethnosphere.

In 2004, Cultural Survival hired Ellen L. Lutz, a human rights attorney who previously taught at the Fletcher School of Law and Diplomacy, as its Executive Director. Lutz led the organization from 2004-2010. Under her leadership, Cultural Survival went through a strategic planning process, stabilized financially, increased the number of indigenous members on its Board of Directors, and placed increased focus on emphasizing indigenous human rights globally. During this time, Cultural Survival also began sponsoring the Guatemala Radio Project, an effort with Guatemalan nongovernmental organizations to create a network of originally over 160 Mayan community radio stations in Guatemala. In 2007, Cultural Survival partnered with Native American organizations and tribal governments "to persuade the United States Congress to fund legislation providing federal support for language immersion programs." In 2009, Lutz also oversaw the merger of Cultural Survival and Global Response, a similarly focused nongovernmental organization.

In 2007, Cultural Survival also saw the passing of the United Nations Declaration on the Rights of Indigenous Peoples, a landmark event that Cultural Survival had worked toward from its early days, as it had actively worked toward the UN passing a resolution in 1992 regarding the International Year of the World's Indigenous People in 1993.

Since 2010, Suzanne Benally (Navajo and Santa Clara Tewa), who was previously Associate Provost and Associate Vice President for Academic Affairs at Naropa Univeristy, has served as the Executive Director of Cultural Survival. The current Deputy Executive Director, Mark Camp, has been with Cultural Survival since 1998, when he started as the organization's Membership Coordinator and the editor of Cultural Survival Voices. As of 2014, Cultural Survival's current programs include "support and expansion of Indigenous owned and operated community radio, … support and advocacy for community based language revitalization programs"; Cultural Survival Quarterly; Bazaars; the Global Response Program; and the Free, Prior, and Informed Consent Initiative, which seeks to increase "awareness and understanding of this right through community media and community exchanges."

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: This collection contains some restricted material. Restrictions related to specific material are listed in the detailed contents list.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Some material in this collection may be protected by copyright and other rights. Please see "Reproductions and Use" on the Digital Collections and Archives website for more information about reproductions and permission to publish. No documentation is available regarding the intellectual property rights in this collection.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series includes staff research, non-staff investigations sponsored by Cultural Survival, and files of Cultural Survival Projects and Special Projects kept by Ted Macdonald in his roles as Project Director (1979-1992) and Director of Research (1993-1995). The bulk of the records date from 1979-1993. Included are project summaries and status reports from projects located in Australia, Bolivia, Chile, Brazil, Canada, Colombia, Ecuador, El Salvador, Guatemala, Honduras, Iraq, Japan, Mexico, Nepal, Nicaragua, Pakistan, Panama, Paraguay, Peru, Philippines, Siberia, the United States, and Venezuela. Files include background information and financial reports from Regional Coordinator for Bolivia and Colombia, Nicanor Gonzalez; initiatives in environmental protection and natural resource management; health studies; general correspondence; educational materials; project reports and proposals; curriculum for bilingual education; Peruvian land demarcation studies; workshop notes; trip reports and itineraries; computer database project files; land tenure research; and staff meeting minutes. Some materials focus on dealings of Cultural Survival Enterprises, including with funding agencies.

The first few folders include general projects lists and brief descriptions of each project (as gathered by Cultural Survival and not necessarily including all projects) and indexes found in filing cabinets listing country and subject codes(many of which were noted on the folders).

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Materials are arranged under Cultural Survival Projects; Cultural Survival Special Projects; Cultural Survival Files; and Cultural Survival Enterprises Files. Material related to Cultural Survival Projects is arranged alphabetically by country and then within each country alphabetically by project title. Coordinator files for a particular country are filed at the beginning of the country (e.g. Nicanor is filed at the beginning of files on Bolivia, and Jim Levy's files are filed at the beginning of Ecuador). Material related to Special Projects are arranged in the same way and filed after the Project files. General Cultural Survival files are arranged alphabetically, with the exception of one folder containing a general summary of Cultural Survival's activities that has been filed before other general files for researchers' benefit. Cultural Survival Enterprises files are arranged alphabetically.

scopecontent.p: Fundac_a_o Nacional do Indio. FUNAI, the National Indian Foundation, is a Brazilian government body that establishes and carries out policies relating to indigenous peoples. FUNAI is responsible for protecting lands traditionally inhabited and used by these communities. FUNAI�s task is to ensure that their rights are respected as set out in the Brazilian Constitution and the Indian Statute. They were founded in 1969 after the genocide of Amazon Indians. Source: http://www.survivalinternational.org/.

scopecontent.p: Consejo Regional Indígena del Cauca.The Indian Council of Cauca (CRIC) was formed in 1972. CRIC's initial purposes were to demarcate and entitle indigenous lands, protect Indian rights and promote Indian culture and education. After 12 years of work in these areas, CRIC restated its priorities to emphasize economic assistance. In its 1984 platform, environmental restoration and production were made first-order priorities. Source: http://www.culturalsurvival.org/publications/cultural-survival-quarterly/colombia/recuperating-devastated-lands-experimental-farm-ca

scopecontent.p: Sna is "the house" and Jolobil means "tissue" in Tzotzil Maya. Includes descriptions of the project.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists of board meeting reports, anthropological studies of indigenous groups called "cultural studies," land inquiries, maps, financial reports, grants, indigenous rights literature, sponsored research, notebooks kept by Ted Macdonald from his time with the Program on Non-Violent Sanctions and Cultural Survival (PONSACS) at Harvard, and PONSACS staff project files. The bulk of the material dates from 1994-2002. A majority of the materials are related to the David Rockefeller Center for Latin American Studies conference and correspondence with petroleum companies called oil dialogues, as well as grant related records, such as proposals for the William and Flora Hewlett Foundation, National Science Foundation, and United States Agency for International Development (USAID).

scopecontent.p: The United States Institute of Peace was established in 1984 by Congress as an independent, nonpartisan federal institution meant to promote the peaceful management and resolution of international conflicts. PONSACS submitted a grant to the USIP for the Schirmer Project and was offered $35,000. The grant focused on the Guatemalan military. The grant proposal was submitted by Dr. Jennifer Schirmer of the John F. Kennedy School of Government.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists of annual reports; financial statements; Board of Directors records, including minutes; staff meeting minutes; budgets; strategic planning records; and correspondence regarding the administration of Cultural Survival. Material dates chiefly from 1988-2012, but some financial records exist from the 1970s. Records of note include Executive Director and strategic planning process files, 2004; internal memos and external audit reports regarding Cultural Survival's organizational structure, circa 1988-1993; and staff exit memos. Few financial records are extant from the late 1980s and early 1990s.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This series is arranged chronologically by year and alphabetically within years.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists of correspondence, research files, project applications and reports, notes, curricula and their attending student conference materials, development files, conference papers, audio tapes, video tapes, photographic slides, intern files, membership records, contracts, and other records produced during the daily work activities of Cultural Survival. The bulk of the material relates to actual or proposed Projects and Special Projects, 1980-2008. Records of note include the papers of Ellen Lutz, who served as Director from 2004-2010; Education department records from student conferences and the Curriculum Resource Program, bulk 1995-2002; and papers of Mac Chapin and the Central America Program, 1991-1993. Also included are records from several projects and special projects, including but not limited to the Guatemala Radio Project (GRP), 2003-2008; The Garifuna Journey, 1995-2004; La FOMMA (Fortaleza de la Mujer Maya), 1996-1998; the Totem Peoples Preservation Project, 1998-2007; the Talo Dam/Djenne project, 1998-2004; and Project Letimaren, 1988-1992, a collaborative project between Cultural Survival and the Federation of Indian Organizations of Napo (FOIN) in Ecuador. Unfortunately, few records remain of other major projects, including Cultural Survival Enterprises.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This series is arranged in four alphabetical runs. The first two alphabetical runs consist of paper records. The third and fourth runs consist of audio tapes and video tapes, respectively.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: 75 years from the date of creation. 20 years from date of creation. Open for research.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists of correspondence, reports, promotional materials, audio and video advertisements, slide shows, photographs, index cards, and sample crafts relating to Cultural Survival Bazaars and other promotional efforts by Cultural Survival. The Bazaar, an annual or semi-annual festival designed to make indigenous art visible and give indigenous artisans a market for their work, was for many years organized by Pia Maybury-Lewis. In more recent years, Bazaars have occurred more frequently and have served as a way for Cultural Survival to fundraise and increase awareness of its programs supporting indigenous issues. The bulk of Bazaar-related records document specific Bazaars in Cambridge, MA; Boston, MA; Northampton, MA; Providence, RI; Tiverton, RI; and other locales held between 1999 and 2006. Also included are staff evaluations of the Bazaar program, promotional flyers, and training materials for Cultural Survival staff working the events. Publicity materials not related to Bazaars include Cultural Survival Slide Shows, flyers for Cultural Survival projects and programs, public service announcements, advertisements, calendars, and recordings of broadcast interviews with Cultural Survival staff.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This series is arranged into two groups: Bazaar and Publicity. Bazaar material is arranged in two alphabetical runs. Publicity material is not arranged.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists of correspondence, research files, promotional materials, contracts, video tapes, and audio tapes relating to the 1992 British and US public television video series Millennium: Tribal Wisdom and the Modern World, hosted by and focused on the work of David Maybury-Lewis. Material dates chiefly from 1988-1992. Cultural Survival's contribution was limited to promoting the series to its networks of members and at several publicity events across the nation, a role that is reflected in the correspondence. A few records indicate various staff members' interest in being included in the television series – including a letter from Jason Clay to the Cultural Survival Board of Directors, circa 1987, proposing that Cultural Survival take on Millennium as a Special Project. Maybury-Lewis's correspondence documents his roles as co-creator, narrator, and adviser on issues such as the script, partnerships, production and post-production work, and fundraising; and includes letters to and from a number of public figures, including Claude Lévi-Strauss, Ursula K. Le Guin, and former Secretary of the Smithsonian Institution Robert McCormick Adams, Jr.. The series also contains a number of research files on indigenous peoples considered for inclusion in the show, videocassettes of the program, and audio tapes of the show's soundtrack.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes copies of letters to and from Claude Lévi-Strauss, Paul Samuelson, Robert McCormick Adams, Jr., Barbara Tuchman, and Alfonso Ortiz.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists of Cultural Survival Quarterly (CSQ) issue number-specific working files, correspondence, and papers relating to the production of the magazine, 1980-2011. CSQ issue number files, 1993-2002, contain records related to the production of specific issues of the magazine. Correspondence, 1980-2011, is largely between Cultural Survival staff and authors or guest editors who contributed to CSQ. Correspondence also concerns article reprint permissions, review materials, advertising, issue planning, administration of the magazine, staff policies, photographs and image rights, intern training materials, popular feedback, printing, and distribution.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This series is arranged into two groups: CSQ issue number files and Correspondence. CSQ issue number files are arranged chronologically by issue number. Correspondence is arranged alphabetically.

scopecontent.p: This series consists chiefly of copies of the Cultural Survival Newsletter and its successor, Cultural Survival Quarterly, 1976-2012. Also included are indices, 1982-1991; a Cultural Survival catalog, 1993; and two Spanish-language issues of Extracta, dated March 1985 and December 1988.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists of Special Reports, Occasional Papers, Cultural Survival Reports, papers, books, and other publications produced by Cultural Survival in addition to Cultural Survival Quarterly. Special Reports, Occasional Papers, and Reports are numbered series. Special Reports were broad papers published between 1979 and 1982. Cultural Survival Reports, first published as Occasional Papers, are timely focused monographs on issues faced by particular indigenous peoples that exceeded acceptable length for Cultural Survival Quarterly. These are sold by Cultural Survival at cost. Also included in this series are copies of Action for Cultural Survival, Cultural Survival Voices, and Rainforest Views, printouts of Active Voices articles published online from 1997-1998, and sheets of microfiche that appear to be copies of Cultural Survival Reports 18-35. In all, this is a very incomplete set of Cultural Survival's publications, as a number of issues are not included.

did.unittitle: Indigenous and indigenous issues video library

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists of documentary and feature films concerning indigenous peoples created by indigenous groups, sympathetic non-profits, and independent filmmakers and subsequently collected by Cultural Survival. The films are in many languages, including English, Spanish, Portuguese, Hungarian, Xavante, Hawaiian, Quechua, and Tuareg. Most but not all non-English language tapes are subtitled in English.
Videos from Cultural Survival events and functions are not included in this series.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This series is arranged alphabetically in two runs. English language films are arranged according to the first word after any initial articles. Foreign-language films are arranged according to the first letter, article included (e.g. "La Dignidad" is filed under L).

The 11 minute video features interviews with community members about the effects of the militarization in Chiapas and the different ways that video technology will be used by the communities to record human rights abuses, cultural and religious events, cooperatives and women's work." The second video "takes an intimate look at the role of men and women in the community of Ejido Morelia. Men and women discuss their individual and collective work. Shot and edited by community members only six weeks after their first exposure to video equipment, this six minute work contains unique shots inside the homes and work places of proud campesinos struggling for a better life" -Publisher's web site (www.chiapasmediaproject.org).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Language: English and Mi'kmaq. Festival version. "The stories of Aboriginal offenders unfold behind the walls of a federal penitentiary (Springhill Institution in Nova Scotia) as Robert, David and George struggle with issues of mercy and healing within a man-made institution designed to deter and punish. Gilbert Sanipass, a Mi'kmaq elder, brings his wisdom into the prison, and introduces members of the Native Brotherhood Association to their culture and traditions for the first time. Looks at the Kwikwexwelhp Healing Lodge on the West Coast as an example of an effective means of combining corrections with Aboriginal healing and culturally-based programming, to enable a more productive reintegration into society."

Major Mary's charismatic storytelling is accompanied by rare, clandestine footage smuggled out of the refugee camps along the border between Burma and Thailand. The film reveals the Karen refugees' spirit and determination to survival as political and historical forces conspire against them."

Indigenous and indigenous issues reference library

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists of journals and newsletters published by indigenous groups as well as non-profit and development organizations focusing on indigenous issues that were originally part of a larger Cultural Survival reference library. The publications cover issues faced by particular indigenous groups and indigenous peoples as a whole. The series also includes several directories of indigenous organizations, 1988-2005. Academic, indigenous, and commercial publications that are widely available in the United States are not included in the collection, nor is Cultural Survival's extensive book collection.

Please note that reference library may be something of a misnomer, as Cultural Survival never had a cohesive reference library per se. Rather, books, journals, and visual materials were collected by individual staff members at their desks for their individual research or projects. These smaller collections were sometimes collated into more comprehensive libraries at various times. By 2012, there was one basement library room containing books and journals; others were stored throughout the office premises in Cambridge.

Publications in this series are written in English, Spanish, Portuguese, Quechua, German, Tzotzil, Hawaiian, French, Italian, Hungarian, Australian aboriginal languages, Guaraní, Russian, Buryat, Inuit, Zulu, and Dutch.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This series is largely arranged alphabetically by publication title.

scopecontent.p: Departamento de Ciências Sociais e Filosofia Area de Antropologia - ILCSE/UNESP [Department of Social Science and Philosophy, Area of Anthropology], São Paulo, Brasil, 1982. The Centro de Estudos Indigenas, formerly known as the Grupo de Estudos Indigenas Kurumim (GEIK), was foundedas an affiliate of the University of the State of Sao Paulo - Araraquara. It is concerned with studying the adaptation of Indians to their eco-system and their interaction with others. The Center works to publicize the state of the Brazilian Indians, little known in urban Brazil, and to fight for a due respect for these peoples, and their frequently violated rights.

It was created in the 'First Encounter of the Indian Movements of South America' in Ollantaytambo, Cusco, Peru, in 1980. CISA is a base member of the World Concil of Indigenous Peoples (CMPI) and the Nongovernmental organization (ONG) of the United Nations (ONU). CISA, to systematize and speed up communication between Indian and non-Indian Peoples of America and the World, has created its mouthpieces: the Magazine 'Indian People' and news organ: 'CISA Bimonthly Informative Bulletin.'"
